County Energy Snapshot of Autauga County, AL
This snapshot outlines potential electricity generation and storage technology opportunities in Autauga County, AL
Baseline Data
2025 Modeled Autauga County, AL Energy Use

Chart

Pie chart with 8 slices.
Transportation​Electricity 0.5%​Transportation​Electricity 0.5%
Transportation​Non-Electricity 50.6%​Transportation​Non-Electricity 50.6%
Industrial​Natural​Gas 26.1%​Industrial​Natural​Gas 26.1%
Residential​Electricity 4.6%​Residential​Electricity 4.6%
Residential​Non-Electricity 2.6%​Residential​Non-Electricity 2.6%
Commercial​Electricity 10.3%​Commercial​Electricity 10.3%
Commercial​Non-Electricity 4.3%​Commercial​Non-Electricity 4.3%
End of interactive chart.
Modeled* Energy Consumption by Sector in 2025

Chart

Bar chart with 8 bars.
The chart has 1 X axis displaying categories.
The chart has 1 Y axis displaying values. Data ranges from 0.0144243418908276 to 0.4677968692533836.
0.128​0.128
0.020​0.020
0.311​0.311
0.038​0.038
0.014​0.014
0.468​0.468
0.179​0.179
0.020​0.020

Residential Non-Electricity
Commercial Electricity
Commercial Non-Electricity
Transportation Electricity
Transportation Non-​Electricity
Industrial Natural Gas
Industrial Electricity
0
0.1
0.2

0.4
0.5
End of interactive chart.
Modeled* CO₂ Generation by Sector in 2025 (Million Metric Tons)
*Information presented for 2025 is based on modeled results. Such results have been calibrated against historical data, but they will not match exactly with reported energy data. This model does not include air, marine, or train transportation.
Energy Usage Reduction Potential

Autauga County could achieve a

45% reduction in energy-related carbon dioxide (CO₂) between 2025 and 2035

in a gradual grid modernization by 2050 and widespread electrification scenario, which would also result in the following air quality benefits:

NOₓ
60% reduction
in Nitrogen Oxides (NOₓ)
SO₂
43% reduction
in Sulfur Dioxide (SO₂)
Affordability in Energy Planning

Autauga County has

2 census tracts
with high transportation burden (>4.2% of income spent on transportation)

and

1 census tract
with high household energy burden (>6% of income spent on energy bills)

Tract 211 has the highest housing energy burden.

Housing Energy
Transportation
Household Energy and Transportation Burden
Transportation Electrification

If Autauga County pursued high electrification, the transportation sector could see

29,120 personally owned light-duty battery electric vehicles

registered by 2050.

Chart

Pie chart with 4 slices.
Conventional Gasoline ​16,220​Conventional Gasoline ​16,220
Battery Electric ​29,120​Battery Electric ​29,120
Hybrid Gasoline ​3,060​Hybrid Gasoline ​3,060
Plug-In Hybrid ​6,400​Plug-In Hybrid ​6,400
End of interactive chart.
Light Duty Vehicle Electrification Potential, 2050

High electrification between 2025 and 2050 could result in:

65% reduction
in personally owned light-duty vehicle gasoline consumption
150 GWh increase
in electricity demand
Residential Energy Efficiency Opportunities

Autauga County low-to-moderate income households in single-family homes could see

average annual energy bill savings of 39%

by implementing a maximally cost-effective energy efficiency upgrade package.

Chart

Bar chart with 3 bars.
The chart has 1 X axis displaying categories.
The chart has 1 Y axis displaying 2015 Dollars ($) Per Year. Data ranges from 69.25 to 467.22.
2015 Dollars ($) Per Year
Electricity
Propane
Natural Gas
0
100
200
300
400
500
End of interactive chart.
Average Annual Energy Bill Savings Per Low-to-Moderate Income Single-Family Home in Autauga County
Commercial Energy Efficiency Opportunities

Autauga County has an estimated 90 buildings over 50,000 square feet. Industrial buildings have the largest building area among buildings over 50,000 square feet in Autauga County.

Chart

Pie chart with 5 slices.
Industrial​5,150,940​Industrial​5,150,940
Specialty​160,230​Specialty​160,230
Retail​2,755,650​Retail​2,755,650
Hospitality​290,470​Hospitality​290,470
Multifamily​4,607,890​Multifamily​4,607,890
End of interactive chart.
Commercial Building Area of Buildings > 50,000 square feet (2020) in Autauga County (sq ft)
Adding heat recovery
has the highest commercial building gas savings potential in Alabama
Upgrading to LED interior lighting
has the highest commercial building electricity savings potential in Alabama
Electricity Generation
Utility-scale photovoltaics (PV)
Autauga County has 290 times more utility-scale PV technical generation potential than residential rooftop PV.
Utility-scale wind
Autauga County has 1.4 times less utility-scale land-based wind technical generation potential than distributed wind.
Residential rooftop PV
In Autauga County, the 2024 levelized cost of electricity from residential rooftop PV was 1.5 times more expensive than utility-scale PV.
Distributed wind
In Autauga County, the 2024 levelized cost of electricity from behind-the-meter distributed wind was ∞ times less expensive than utility-scale land-based wind.
Learn more at https://maps.nrel.gov/slope
